The plain style – what it is, and how it’s used
The informal style
How to say I’ll have to (go away and) think about it
Sentences with toe- (it’s okay to … and it has become)
Asking if someone feels like doing something with -(ǔ)llaeyo
How to say even though it looks similar …

chapter.title: Do you have a spare room?/The towel is dirty and the food is cold
chapter.para: In this unit you will learn

emphasis.emphasis: about booking hotels and inquiring about vacancies and facilities
about making complaints when things don’t go quite as they should
more about the formal style of speech and the future tense
quoted speech and reporting what other people said

sect1.title: Do you have a spare room?
sect1.para: Mr Lee is looking for a couple of rooms in a hotel.

entry.para: Ne, issǒyo. Ch’imdaebang-ǔl tǔrilkkayo, ondolbang-ǔl tǔrilkkayo?
Ch’imdaebang-ǔn haru-e oman won-i-go ondolbang-ǔn haru-e samman won-i-mnida.
Usǒn sam-il dongan-yo. Kǔrigo chom tǒ mug-ǔljido mollayo.
O-il isang yeyak ha-shimyǒn o-p’ǒsent’ǔ harin hae-tǔrinǔndeyo.
A, kǔrǒm uri chipsaram-hago chom ǔynon hae-bwayagessǒyo.
Ne, mullon ach’im shiksa-do p’oham toeǒ issǔmnida. Ilgop-shi-but’ǒ yǒl-shi sai-e chiha shiktang-e ka-shimyǒn toemnida.
Kǔrigo ich’ǒn won-man tǒ nae-shimyǒn sonnim pang-kkaji paedal-do hae-dǔrimnida.
Aniyo, chickchǒp shiktang-e ka-sǒ mǒkkessǒyo. I-hot’er-e tto musǔn shisǒl-dǔr-i issǔmnikka?
Suyǒngjang, sauna, orakshil, noraebang, sǔt’endǔba, kǔrigo hanshiktang-gwa yangshiktang-i issǔmnida.
O, aju hullyung ha-gunyo! O-il dongan yeyak hanǔn ke cho-ǔl kǒt kat’ayo. Ama uri chipsaram-do choa ha-lkǒeyo.

para.emphasis: how long will you be staying for?
we may stay longer (I don’t know if we might …)
I’ll have to discuss it with my wife
we’ll go to the restaurant to eat
o-il dongan yeyak hanŭn ke cho-ŭl kŏt kat’ayo
it seems like it would be a good idea to book for five nights

entry.para: empty, vacant, free (of seats and rooms)

sect2.para: The formal style is the last important speech style for you to learn. It is used in formal situations, often by officials or representatives (such as the hotel worker in the dialogue), but it can be used by anybody when some formality is called for. It is perhaps slightly more common among men than women and, if you are a man, it is a good idea to say some sentences in the formal style occasionally, as if you always use the polite style it can sound to Koreans as though your Korean is a bit effeminate. It is quite common to mix formal and polite speech styles in this way, with some sentences in the formal style and some in the polite style.

To make statements in the formal style (that is, normal sentences which state facts, not questions, commands or suggestions), you add the ending –(-[sŭ]mnida) to the stem of the verb (either the present stem, past stem, or honorific present or past stem). Note that the ending is spelt -(sŭ)pnida, but pronounced -(sŭ)mnida. To consonant stems you add the form –(-sŭmnida), and to vowel stems –(-mnida):

Note that the past formal forms have a treble -s, and so are spelt for example, (sass-sŭmnida). We just write two ss in romanization, however. You will recognize these formal statements from expressions like (mian hamnida), (choesong hamnida) and (algessŭmnida). All those expressions are almost always used in the formal style.
To make questions in the formal style, you add the ending –?(-[sŭ]mnikka?) as follows:
Commands in the formal style always go on honorific present stems, and the ending is –(-pshio) (pronounced rather as if it were –[-pshiyo]):
You have already learned how to make suggestions in the formal style, way back in the early lessons of the course: – (-[ŭ]pshida); (ibǔpshida) (let’s wear it), (sapshida) (let’s buy it)
Note that this form can be added to an honorific stem, to express the feeling of formal style: (ibushipshida), (sashipshida).

sidebar.para: The formal style is used in formal situations to talk to people older or more important than you, or to show respect. You don’t have to use it all the time; speakers will often mix their styles between the polite and the formal style in the same conversation. This is perfectly okay.
To make the formal style, add the form – (-sǔmnida); (-sǔmnikka) for questions to verb stems ending in a consonant; and add – (-mnida); (-mnikka) for questions to verb stems ending in vowels.

sect2.title: 2 The future marker (-kess)
sect2.para: The future marker – (-kess) can be added to any present stem (normal or honorific) to make a future stem. You can then add verb endings to this (such as the polite or formal styles, or a clause ending, such as –[-jiman]) in the normal way. You have two good examples in this unit:

listitem.para: (Ǒlma dongan mugǔshi-gess-ǒyo)?

para.emphasis: How long will you be staying for?
I will have to discuss with my wife …

sect2.para: The – future marker is used in the ending – (-yagessǒyo) (as in the second example) which you have already learned. It is also used in certain idiomatic phrases like (algessŭmnida) and (morǔgessŭmnida) (I understand and I don’t understand).

Although this form does express the future (it can also be used to express probability), the most common way to put a normal sentence into the future is with the – (-[ŭ]l kŏeyo) form which you have already learned. – is a more useful form than – for most situations, and the precise difference between them is something that you do not really need to worry about for this course. It is sufficient to be able to recognize the – as the future marker, and to know that it can be used to make future stems which can then be used in other constructions.

sidebar.para: The future marker – – (-kess-) can be added to verbs to specify a future sense; verb endings are then added in the normal way, in whatever style is appropriate for the conversation. However, the most common way of making a future form is to use the – (-[ǔ]l kǒeyo) form that you learned much earlier in this course.

sect2.para: You can say that you don’t know whether you will do something or other by adding –-(-[ǔ]lji-do morǔ-) to a verb stem. The example from the dialogue was (chom tŏ mug-ǔlji-do mollayo) (I don’t know whether we will stay a bit longer, it might be that we stay a bit longer). Here are a couple of other examples:

para.emphasis: I don’t know whether I’ll graduate (or not)
I don’t even know if I’ll be able to go or not

title.emphasis: 4 If you do, it will be okay

sect2.para: The sentence (ka-shimyŏn toemnida) means if you go, it will be okay, and this pattern, one clause ending in –(-myŏn), plus a form of the verb (toe-) is a common pattern. In the context of the dialogue, it is used to say that breakfast is available between certain times, so that if they go to the restaurant between those times, it will be okay. It can be used to ask for permission to do something: (chigŭm ka-myŏn toeyo)? (is it okay to go now?).

A very similar pattern is used in the next dialogue, where there is a similar sentence to this: (chŏ-hant’e mal ha-myŏn an toeyo)? (can’t you tell me? if you tell me, won’t it be okay?). A similar use would be (pakk-e naga-myŏn an toemnikka)? (can’t I go outside? won’t it be okay if I go outside?).

The next dialogue is quite advanced in parts and you should be satisfied if you understand the gist of what is going on. If you can understand the details of the dialogue then you can be sure that your Korean is coming on very well indeed.

sidebar.para: Giving permission. Use the form – (-[ǔ]myon toeyo) to give permission.

title.emphasis: The towel is dirty and the food is cold

sect2.para: Unfortunately, the hotel didn’t turn out to be as good as it looked …

entry.para: I-hot’el sǒbisǔ-e taehaesǒ ha-l mar-i issǒyo.
Choesong ha-jiman chǒ-hant’e malssǔm ha-shimyǒn an toe-lkkayo?
I-hot’el sǒbisǔ-e munje-ga man-ǔn kǒt kat’ayo. Chigwon-dǔr-i pulch’injǒl ha-go muttukttuk haeyo. Kǔrigo onǔl ach’im-e shiktang-e kannǔnde ǔmshig-i ta shigǒ issǒssǒyo. Ǒje-do mach’angaji-yǒt-goyo.
Kǔrǒnde agasshi-ga pulch’inchǒlha-ndedaga che hangung mar-ǔl mot aradǔt-ket-tago ha-myǒnsǒ ǔmshig-e amu munje-ga ǒp-tago haessǒyo.
Ǔmshig-i ta shig-ǒt-ko mash-i ǒmnǔnde-do mar-ieyo.
Hangsang ch’oesǒn-ǔy pongsa-rǔl ha-ryǒgo noryǒk hanǔnde-do kakkǔm shilsu-ga palsaeng hamnida. Chega chǔkshi shiktang chongǒbwon-dǔr-ege yaegi ha-gessǔmnida.
Kǔrigo tto issǒyo. Onǔl ach’im sugǒn-ǔl kara-dallago haennǔnde sugǒn-i nǒmu tǒrǒwossǒyo. Kǔrigo nae adǔl pang-ǔn ajik-kkaji ch’ǒngso-do an haessǒyo.
Sonnim ch’ǒrǒm pulp’yǒng hanǔn kyǒngu-ga chigǔm-kkaji ǒpsǒnnǔndeyo.
Kǔ-gǒt-ppun-i anieyo. Nae pang-ǔy t’ellebijyǒn-ǔn kojang nat-ko naengjanggo mun-ǔn yǒlli-ji-do anayo. Soljikhi mal hae-sǒ i-hot’el sǒbisǔ-hago shisǒr-ǔn ǒngmang-i-neyo.
Choesong hamnida. Kǔrǒch’iman chǒhǔy-dosonnim-ch’ǒrǒm pulp’yǒng manǔn saram-ǔn p’iryo ǒps-ǔnikka onǔl tangjang naga-juseyo. Yogǔm-ǔn tashi hwanpul hae-dǔrigessǔmnida.

para.emphasis: I have something to say about …
wouldn’t it be all right to tell me?
(she) said that there wasn’t any problem
I’m saying (emphasis!) that the food even tasted bad
I asked (her) to change the towel
honestly speaking; to tell the truth; in fact …

entry.para: speak, say (of someone honorific, often in phrase malssǔm haseyo!)
please tell me, please say it (honorific)

para.emphasis: be unhelpful, be unkind, be impolite
be bad, have gone off, cold, be stale etc.

entry.para: on top of (clause ending, onto verbs, like the -nǔnde pattern)
understand (l/t verb like tul-, listen; ara-dǔrǒyo, ara-dǔt-ko etc.)
saying (this pattern shows quoted speech; see note 4)
change (a towel, a platform, clothes etc.)
be dirty (polite: tǒrǒwoyo, p-verb like kakkap- etc.)

sect2.title: 1 Concerning
sect2.para: You can say what you are talking, discussing, writing or reading about in Korean with the construction –(-e taehaesǒ) which is added to the noun which describes what it is you are talking about. Here are some examples:

listitem.para: (chǒngch’i-e taehaesǒ iyagi haessǒyo)
(sǒbisǔ-e taehaesǒ pulp’yǒng haessǒyo)
(nalssi-e taehaesǒ murǒ-bwassǒyo)

sect2.para: We have already taught you a bit about the future modifier –(-[ǔ]l) and here is the opportunity to give you a few more examples, the first one taken from the dialogue. You will remember that modifiers are added to verbs which then modify or describe the noun which they precede. We’ve put the modifier phrase in brackets to help you spot the pattern, and likewise its literal meaning in English:

listitem.para: (sǒbisǔ-e taehaesǒ (ha-l mar-i) issǒyo)

para.emphasis: (words to say) I’ve got some things to say about the service

listitem.para: ([ka-l shigan-i] twaessǒyo)?
(time to go) is it time to go? (lit. has it become time to go?)
(chib-e (mǒg-ǔl kǒsh-i) issǒyo)?

para.emphasis: (thing to eat) is there anything to eat at home?

sect2.para: You have learned the word (kedaga) which means on top of that and you can use a similar form to add to verbs. You use the –(-[ŭ]nde) or –(-nŭnde) imminent elaboration form plus –(-daga), so that the completed forms look like (cho-ŭndedaga) (on top of being good); (ka-nŭndedaga) (on top of going) and so on. Here are two examples in sentences:

para.emphasis: These clothes are good quality and, on top of that, they’re cheap

listitem.para: (Pi-ga o-nǔndedaga ch’uwoyo)

para.emphasis: It’s raining and, on top of that, it’s cold

sect2.title: 4 Quotations and reported speech
sect2.para: This unit introduces you to the rather complicated matter of reported speech in Korean. Reported speech is when you say what someone else said to you. For example, ‘He said he was going to the shops.’ What the person said literally, of course, was ‘I’m going to the shops’, but when we report what someone said we change it to something like, ‘He said he was going to the shops.’ This section is designed so that you will be able to recognize reported speech in Korean and use some of the forms yourself. It is not designed to teach reported speech comprehensively. If you wish to know more, you should consult an advanced grammar book. What we tell you here is more than you need to get by.

To report speech in Korean you use the plain style of the verb: (mŏng-nunda), (sanda), (kanda), (chot’a) etc., plus –(-ko ha-). Remember that the plain style can be formed on any verb stem – past present or future, and honorifics. Here are three examples: the first sentence gives you what the person actually said, the second one gives the reported speech form, ‘he said’ or ‘he says’:

entry.para: (chib-e kanda-go haeyo)) (plain style of ) he says he’s going home
(saram-dǔ r-i mansǔmnida) there are a lot of people
(saram-dǔ r-i mant’a-go haessǒ yo)) (plain style of ) he said there were a lot of people
the weather was good (Mr Kim speaking)
(Kim sǒ nsaengnim-i nalssi-ga choat-tago haessǒ yo) (plain style past of ) Mr Kim said that the weather had been good

sect2.para: Note that suggestions and commands can be quoted in the same way:

entry.para: (chib-e kaja-go haessǒ yo) ( = plain style suggestion of ) he suggested we go home
(pap mdg-ǔrago haessdyo) he told (him/me) to eat his/my food

sect2.para: Questions are a little more complicated and you only need to be able to recognize them as having –(-nya-) or –(-nunya-) in them: you will then know what they are when someone uses the form.

sidebar.para: To report what someone said, put the verb in the plain style, and add – (-ko haessǒyo) to the end.

sect2.para: You can say that you are doing something while you are doing something else by adding –(-[ŭ]myŏnsŏ) to the ‘while’ clause. For example, to say that you were talking (while you watched TV), you would say: (t’ellebijyŏn-ǔl po-myŏnsŏ iyagi haessŏyo). Here are a couple of other examples.

listitem.para: (Hangung mal paeu-myǒnsǒ ǔmag-ul turǒyo)

para.emphasis: I listen to music while I study Korean

listitem.para: (Mǒg-ǔmyǒnsǒ mal hae-boseyo)

para.emphasis: Please tell me while you’re eating

sect2.title: 6 Even though: (-nǔnde-do)
sect2.para: You have learned the imminent elaboration form –(-nǔnde) which indicates that you have not finished what you are saying yet and that there is more to come. You have also learned –(-do), added to the polite style minus –(-yo) to mean even though. The combined form -(-nǔndedo) also means even though (so and so), but has a stronger emphasis than simply –. Thus, (noryŏk ha-nǔnde-do kakkǔm shilsu-ga palsaeng hamnida) (from the dialogue) means even though we (really) are trying, occasionally mistakes happen.

The other – form from the dialogue is a way of putting special emphasis on what you have just said. You saw it in the phrase (ŭmshig-i ta shig-ŏt-go mash-i ŏmnŭnde-do marieyo). The waiter had just told Mr Lee that there was no problem with the food, and then Mr Lee adds: even though (despite the fact that) the food was off and was tasteless. The (mar-ieyo) bit on the end means something like that’s what I’m saying and adds strong emphasis to what has just been said.

sect2.title: 7 Quoted requests
sect2.para: Back to reported speech again. When you ask something to be done for your benefit (by using a compound verb with (chu-), as in (hae-juseyo) (please do it for me) and then report what you have just said, as in I asked him to (do it for me), there is a special rule to remember. Instead of saying something like ( [hae-ju-rago]) (haessŏyo), you swop the verb (chu-) and the –(-ra-) which follows it with the verb (talla), to give (hae-dallago haessŏyo) (I asked him to do it for me).

You saw this in the phrase (sugŏn-ǔl karadallago haennǔndedo …) (I asked her to change the towels for me …). Do not worry about this pattern; this note is merely to explain what is going on in the dialogue and to enable you to recognize the form.

listitem.para: You are thinking of sending your children to a new school in Korea and you have a meeting with one of the teachers to chat about the school. Before you go, you jot down some questions you want to ask about the school. Can you put them into Korean in full sentences?

para.emphasis: Is it possible to study Korean and Chinese?

listitem.para: How many students studying Korean? (how many: )

para.emphasis: Is it okay to go home to eat at lunchtime?

listitem.para: You go to make a booking at a hotel with the following requirements. The receptionist asks you the following questions, for which you must prepare answers in Korean.
: child)
Put the following sentences into the formal style.
Translate the following sentences into English.
Ask if there are the following facilities at the hotel at which you are staying.
Translate the following into Korean.

para.emphasis: How long are you booking for?
I told the bank clerk immediately.
What facilities are there at the hotel?
There seem to be a lot of problems with my car.
My son still hasn’t got up.
We’ll go straight to the bar and have a drink.
Mr Kim is an impolite person.
It would be a good idea to stay for three nights.

listitem.para: Your hotel room has a few problems, as you can see in the picture. Write out a series of complaints, making your language as strong as you can.
Asking for a room/checking availability of accommodations
Checking if breakfast is included
Responding when someone asks how long you will be staying for
Asking what facilities a hotel has
The formal style – what it is and how to recognize it
The future particle and modifier
How to ask for the manager
How to complain
How to say the food was cold and the service was bad!
The expression to say that something does or doesn’t work/is broken

chapter.title: Two to Taegu/I don’t want to go there!
chapter.para: In this unit you will learn

emphasis.emphasis: how to ask for information about catching the train you want
how to discuss going out for meals and drinks together

entry.para: Onǔl chǒnyǒk Taegu kanǔn kich’a-ga innayo?
Ne. Tu kaji-ga innǔndeyo. Wanhaeng-ǔn tasǒt-shi samship-pun-igo chikhaeng-ǔn ilgop-shi sashibo-bun-ieyo.
Chikhaeng-ǔn se shigan kǒlli-go, wanhaeng-ǔn ne shigan samship-pun kǒllimnida.
Wanhaeng-ǔn man p’alch’ǒn won-igo, chikhaeng-ǔn samman och’ǒn won-imnida. Chikhaeng-ǔn chwasǒg-i ǒlma nam-ji anassǔmnida.
Ne chari-rǔl hamkke yeyak ha-l su iss-ǔlkkayo?
Chamkkan-man kidaryǒ-boseyo. Hwagin chom hae-bogessǔmnida. A, ne.
Ne chari-ga it-kunyo. Hǔbyǒnsǒg-ǔl wonhaseyo, kǔmyǒnsǒg-ǔl wonhaseyo?
Ajik morǔmnida. Ch’ulbal shigan jǒn-e chǒnkwangp’an-ǔl pwa-juseyo.

para.emphasis: there are only a few left

entry.para: fast train, express train (also called saemaǔl[ho])

sect2.title: 1 (-ǔlkkayo) To ask questions
sect2.para: In some of the earlier units of this course you learned (-ŭlkkayo) as a pattern meaning shall we? As you will have seen in this unit, it is also sometimes used to ask a question: (ne chari-rǔl hamkke yeyak ha-l su issŭlkkayo)? (is it possible to book four seats together?). There are several patterns like this in Korean where certain verb endings do not always have their basic meaning. The context will always make clear to you which is the correct meaning and in most cases does mean shall we? and is used to make suggestions.

sect2.title: 2 Making requests
sect2.para: Koreans have a word for favour (as in do a favour for someone), (put’ak) and you saw it used in the sentence (kŭmyŏnsŏg-ǔro put’ak hamnida). To say I have a favour to ask, you say either ([che-ga] put’ak issŏyo) and then say what the request is or else say the request, and then add (put’ak hamnida) or (put’ak haeyo) (please, I ask you to do it as a favour).

sidebar.para: Favours. Add (put’ak hamnida) or (put’ak haeyo) either before or after the request to make it extra polite!

sect2.title: 2 Before and after
sect2.para: You have already learned the nouns (chŏn) and (hu) which mean before and after, respectively. They can be used with nouns, as in (ch’ulbal shigan jŏn-e) (before the time of departure), or (shiksa hu-e) (after the meal). They can also be used with verbs, although in a slightly different way.
To say before (verb) you add (-ki jŏn-e) to the stem, as in the following examples: (shijak ha-gi jŏn-e) (before we begin …) or (hakkyo-e ka-gi jŏn-e) (before (I/you) go to school).

sidebar.para: ‘Before’. Add (-ki jǒn-e) after a verb to make a before clause. (manna-ki jǒn-e) means before (we) meet.

sect2.para: To say after (verb) you add (-[ŭ]n hu-e) (or (-[ŭ]n taum-e), which has the same meaning) to the verb stem of a processive verb. This is the past modifier which you have already learned (the present modifier, you will recall, is , as in , e.g. (mŏg-ŭn hu-e) (after eating); (hakkyo-e ka-n taum-e) (after going to school).

In the next dialogue there is more new grammar, but the most important thing is the colloquial language that is used. There are several examples of constructions being used in ways similar to, but not quite the same as, what you have seen before and your aim should be to get the drift of what is going on, and not to be put off by the colloquialisms and (at times) seeming lack of grammar rules! This is what it will be like when you first go to Korea and listen to Koreans talking to each other. With a little practice at concentrating on the drift of what is being said, you will find that the Korean you have learned in this course will stand you in good stead.

sect1.title: I don’t want to go there!
sect1.para: Some colleagues are discussing what they will do after work.

entry.para: Onǔl chǒnyǒk il kkǔnna-go mwo ha-l kǒeyo?
Il kkǔnna-go-yo? Morǔgessǒyo. Ajik kyehoek ǒpsǒyo.
Cho-ǔn saenggag-ineyo. Kǔrǒnde uri tǔl-man kayo?
Tarǔn saram-do purǔ-jiyo. Kim sǒnsaeng-hago I sǒnsaeng-hant’e yaegi hae-bolkkayo?
Cho-ch’iyo. Ǒi, Kim sǒnsaeng, I sǒnsaeng! Onǔl chǒnyǒk pap mǒg-ǔmyǒnsǒ soju han jan ǒttaeyo?
Kǔlsseyo. Kǔnyang pulgogi-hago soju han jan ha-ryǒgoyo. Kǔrigo nasǒ noraebang-e-do ka-go-yo.
Sul mashinǔn kǒn cho-ǔnde chǒ-nǔn pulgogi-nǔn pyǒllo-eyo. Kǔrigo norae hanǔn kǒn ttak chilsaeg-ieyo.
A, kǔrǒm pulgogi malgo tarǔn kǒ mǒg-ǔmyǒn toe- janayo. Kǔrigo norae ha-ji malgo kǔnyang tǔt-kiman haseyo.
Kǔ-gǒ koench’anǔn saenggag-ineyo. Kǔrǒnde onǔl ton-i pyǒllǒ ǒmnǔnde …
Kǒkchǒng maseyo. Onǔl chǒnyǒg-ǔn nae-ga han t’ǒk nae-lgeyo.
Kǔlsseyo. Chǒ-do ka-go ship’ǔnde, chǒ-nǔn Inch’ǒn-e ka-sǒ shingshing han saengsǒn hoe- rǔl mǒk-ko ship’ǔndeyo.
Ei, Inch’ǒn-ǔn nǒmu mǒrǒyo. Kǔrigo saengsǒn hoe-nǔn yojǔm nǒmu pissa-goyo.
Kedaga chǒ-nǔn saengsǒn hoe-rǔl mon mǒgǒyo.
Choayo. Choa. Kǔnyang hae-bon sori-eyo. Onǔr-ǔn chǒ-do ttara-ga-sǒ pulgogi-e soju-na mǒg-ǔl su pakk-e ǒpkenneyo.
I don’t have any plans yet

para.emphasis: is it just the two of us going?
we were just thinking of having a soju
I was just saying it (don’t take it too seriously)
there’s nothing for it (no alternative) but to eat soju
I’ll pay (for everyone); it’s on me

entry.para: hey! (used to call close friends and colleagues)
not (noun), instead of (noun) (when suggesting an alternative)

para.emphasis: have almost none, scarcely have any

entry.para: there is nothing for it but to (verb)

sect2.title: 1 More ways of saying ‘afterwards’
sect2.para: You can add the ending (-ko na-sŏ) to any present tense processive verb base to mean after (verb):
(Il ha-go na-sǒ sul hanjan hapshida)

para.emphasis: After finishing work let’s have a drink

sect2.para: can be abbreviated to (-kosŏ), and sometimes even to just .

sect2.title: 2 Informal sentences
sect2.para: This dialogue shows the way in which Koreans can add particles to the end of verbs in colloquial speech to give extra nuances to what they are saying. They can also make incomplete sentences which they complete simply by adding the polite particle (-yo). You do not need to worry about learning rules for this kind of thing, since in most circumstances you will want to use a more formal and grammatical style of speaking when you begin to speak Korean in Korea. It is very useful to recognize what is going on in colloquial speech, however, and as you spend more time speaking with Koreans you will quickly learn to do this kind of thing for yourself.

sidebar.para: Verbal confusion. To a non-native speaker, Koreans sometimes seem to play fast and loose with their verb endings, mixing and matching particles and endings. Try not to be fazed by this. The main thing is to recognize what the basic verb is in the sentence, e.g. whether it’s a statement, a question or a suggestion, and what the basic drift of the sentence is. In your own speech, you can keep things simpler!

sect2.para: You can miss out the rest of this section if you wish, as the explanation may seem a bit complicated. Your main task should be to completely familiarize yourself with the dialogue, almost to the extent of being able to say it by heart. For the adventurous, however, here are two sentences from the dialogue with an explanation of how they have been constructed.

sect2.title: (Soju han jan haryǒgoyo)
sect2.para: You have previously met the (-[ŭ]ryŏgo) pattern, with the meaning with the intention of. Normally it is used in the pattern (clause A)-ŭryŏgo (clause B), as in (hangung mal paeu-ryŏgo ch’aek sassŏyo), but here the pattern is simply (clause A)-uryŏgo-yo. Clause B has been omitted in casual speech and the polite particle added to round the construction off. The full form would have been something like (soju han jan haryŏgo ŏnǔ sulchib-ina kalkka haeyo) (we were thinking of going to some pub or other to have a drink), but this is cut down to what would translate as to have a drink – or, in better English, we were just thinking of going for a drink and is made into a sentence simply be adding to the pattern.

This means after that (we were thinking of) going to a noraebang too. The at the end is the clause ending that normally means and when you are going to add another clause. However, in this case, the meaning is as well, in addition. This sentence is being added to the one that has been said previously to indicate that this is also part of the plan as well. Then the particle is added to round it all off.

sect2.title: 3 Negatives with (pyǒllo)
sect2.para: Sentences with negative verbs in them (with and ) can be modified by inserting the word (pyŏllo) in them, to mean not particularly. This will be clearer with examples:

para.emphasis: I don’t particularly want to go

sect2.para: The dialogue also has a sentence in it, which is slightly different. (chŏ-nǔn pulgogi-nǔn pyŏllo-eyo). This is a more colloquial form, putting the copula onto the end of the word . But you can see that it is in a sense an abbreviated form of (chŏ-nǔn pulgogi-nǔn pyŏllo choa ha-ji anayo), so the pattern is essentially the same. You should stick to the full form with a negative verb most of the time and leave the colloquial, abbreviated form to native speakers.

sidebar.para: The term (pyǒllo), with a negative verb, is a very useful term which has the meaning of (not) particularly.

sect2.title: 4 Not one thing, but another instead
sect2.para: You can stay instead of (noun), or not (noun) by putting the word (malgo) after the noun, as you can see in these examples:

para.emphasis: Let’s not buy apples, let’s buy meat; instead of apples, let’s buy meat
(chapji malgo shinmun- ǔl ing-nǔn kǒ choa haeyo)
It’s not magazines, it’s newspapers I enjoy reading
How about going to the mountain instead of Pulguksa?

sect2.para: You can use a similar pattern to say instead of (verb). Simply add (-ji malgo) (this is the same [-ji] that you use in the long negative, or in (-ji maseyo)). Look at the following examples, the first is from the dialogue:

para.emphasis: Don’t sing (do a song), just listen (instead)
Don’t drink coffee, have some tea or something instead
(wae kongbu ha-ji malgo iyagi-man hara-go haeyo)?
Why are you staying just talking and not studying (instead)?

sect2.title: 5 Just doing something
sect2.para: The sentence (tǔt-kiman haseyo) means just listen! The form (-kiman ha-) added to processive verbs means just (verb) or only (verb). Here are examples:

para.emphasis: We didn’t say anything, we just ate
Are you only listening (rather than participating)?

sect2.title: 6 There’s nothing for it, but to…
sect2.para: When you feel you have no option but to do something or other, or that you are obliged to do something, you can use the pattern (-[ŭ]l su pakk-e ŏps-). Here are examples:

para.emphasis: There’s nothing for it but to go; I’ll have to go
Although it’s expensive, there’s nothing for it but to buy it

sidebar.para: The form (-[ŭ]l su pakk-e ǒpsǒyo) is used to mean there’s nothing for it but to… or I’m going to have to … It’s a relatively common form, and worth remembering.

listitem.para: Translate the following sentences into English.
For each of the following, say that you will go out before doing them and then that you will go out after doing them.
Look at the following information about train availability and then answer the questions.
Make up three sentences saying that there is nothing for it but to …

para.emphasis: get up at six in the morning

listitem.para: Make up a set of sentences, each one using the following sets of information and using (noun) or (verb) . For example, for the first one you could make up a sentence which said I want to eat fruit, not meat.
Translate the following sentences into Korean.

para.emphasis: Buy something to eat before the departure time.
Shall we have a talk to your parents?
I’d like to go, too, but it’s a long way.
Can I book three seats together?
Let’s go to Inchǒn, not to Seoul.
What shall we do after finishing work?
When are you going to come back?
Do you like eating raw fish?

listitem.para: The terms for before and after
How to say you don’t particularly want to go, or that you don’t find something particularly interesting
The construction for there’s nothing for it but to …
Saying instead of (e.g. let’s buy apples instead of bananas)
How to ask if there is a train to Pusan this evening
How to book four non-smoking seats together
How to ask what platform a train leaves from
How to ask how long a journey takes
Asking what someone is doing after work this evening
How to say you’ll pay (for drinks or a meal)

sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: So, you have virtually reached the end of this course. This unit contains more exercises which practise the situations and grammar you have been learning in the last six units. Most of these exercises are Korean to English or English to Korean translations, since that is the best way to check that you have really mastered the material in the units. Make sure you are comfortable with the topics in the list that follows and be sure to revise the grammar notes for any of the major patterns you are not quite happy with. It would be a good idea also to read through all the dialogues in the units once again. You will find there are things that you felt a bit uneasy about at the time that are now clearer to you and you are sure to understand more fully what is going on grammatically in the dialogues. Even though you have reached the end of the course, you will find that simply reading through the dialogues every so often will help you to retain the things you have learned.

sect1.title: Topic revision
sect1.para: The following list shows the main topics that have been covered in the last six units. You should feel capable of handling these topics at a simple level should you need to when you are in Korea. If you feel unsure about a particular topic, you should go over the dialogue again more thoroughly, and revise the expressions and vocabulary that go with it. Of course there will still be many things that you are not able to say in Korean, but with the tools we have given you you should be able to succeed in carrying out many language tasks, some at quite a high level, and should have a more fascinating and enjoyable experience as a result whenever you visit Korea or communicate with Korean people.

listitem.para: advanced phone conversations
cancelling appointments
dating and talking about other people
describing what you did
buying presents
retorting
police officers and traffic offences
lost property
describing objects
feeling ill
getting medicine
buying and comparing clothes
trying on clothes
booking into a hotel and asking about facilities
complaining
train journeys
arranging to go out
Translate the following into English.

For each of the following pictures make up a question which asks if someone has ever tried doing them. Then make up an answer which says yes, I have and another which says you did it yesterday, as a matter of fact. (dance: )
Make up an appropriate response to the following questions or requests.
Translate the following into Korean.

para.emphasis: I really didn’t see the sign.
You can wear it with jeans.
I’m ringing to cancel my appointment.
Is there a telephone and TV in the room?
We bought him socks last year.
I’d like to go to Inchǒn and eat raw fish.
What does your car look like?
Would you write a letter for me?
My head hurts so much I can’t sleep.

listitem.para: Your friend has a new girlfriend and you quiz him about her. Make up questions to fill in the following fact file:
What do together? ________________
Translate the following into English.
Complete the following dialogue.

para.emphasis: (No, an urgent matter has come up. Why?)
(What are you going to buy for him?)
(How about Tuesday? Do you have time then?)

listitem.para: Rewrite the dialogue in question 7 using the informal and plain styles of speech.
Put the following sentences into the formal style.
The following pictures tell what you did last Saturday. Write an account of what you did, putting in as many details as you can according to what the pictures suggest.
Translate the following into Korean.

para.emphasis: I started meeting her often from that time.
Don’t be surprised even if you have no energy (strength).
Although it might look similar, it isn’t.
We’ll go straight to the restaurant and eat.
It’s turned out well then. Goodbye!
What time did you leave our department store?
Would you like to try it on?

entry.para: Hello! How have you been getting along?
Fine, fine. Where are you going?
Right now I’m off to the city centre.
What are you going to do in the city centre?
I’m going to buy some bread.
I’m also going to buy bread in the city centre.
Excuse me/Waiter! Do you have any soju?
Yes, yes. We have. Soju, beer, western spirits – all of them.
Well then, give us a beer and one soju, please.
And we also need some snacks/side dishes. What do you have?
Fruit, squid, dry snacks, p’ajon – we’ve got all of those.
Then give me some fruit and some squid, please.
Yes, that’s right. It’s really been a long time.
How have you been getting along?
Yes, fine. How’s business these days?
Oh, really? Pleased to meet you. I’ve heard a lot about you.
Pleased to meet you. I’m Yunhuy Jang.
I’m Jinyang Kim. I’m pleased that I’ve met you.
Are you the Korean language teacher?
No. I’m not a Korean language teacher. I’m a Japanese language teacher.
Ah, I’m sorry. Isn’t this the Korean department’s office?
No, this isn’t the Korean department. This is the Japanese department.
Right. Where is the Korean department office, please?
Excuse me, is this the Korean department’s office?
Yes. What brings you here? (Can I help you?)
I’ve come to meet the Korean language teacher.
Hello? I’m sorry, but can I speak to Mr Kim, please?
There is no such person here.
No. You’ve dialled the wrong number.
Hello? I’m sorry, but can I speak to Mr Kim, please?
Ah, hello. I’m Tony from the British embassy.
Ah, hello! Long time, no see!
Do you have any free time this lunchtime?
Then I’d like to buy you lunch.
Yes, fine. Let’s meet at 12 in front of Lotte Hotel.
Great. So, I’ll see you in a little while.

sect2.title: Are you ready to order yet?

entry.para: Welcome! Please take a seat over here.
Would you like anything to drink?
We’ll have some beer first, please.
Yes, I like it a lot, but I can’t eat spicy food so well.
Then let’s eat pulgogi or kalbi.
Yes, fine. And I’d like to eat some naengmyon as well.
Pulgogi for two people and two dishes of naengmyon, please.
Would you like water naengmyon or pibim naengmyon?
Waiter! More water and more kimchi, please.
Yes, I’d like both a Korean–English dictionary and an English–Korean dictionary.
Each volume is 10,000 won; 20,000 won all together.
Do you have Chinese character dictionaries also?
We have three kinds of Chinese character dictionary.
Just a moment … here it is.
Thank you. How much is it altogether?
The Chinese character dictionary is 30,000 won … therefore altogether it’s 50,000 won.
The cheapest one is 30,000 won? How much is the most expensive one, then?! 100,000 won?!
Oh, I’m sorry; I’ve made a mistake. It’s 30,000 won altogether. Would you like a receipt?
Excuse me, can you tell me where the bank is around here?
If you go left at that post office over there, there is the Sangŏp bank.
I’d like to change some English money into Korean money.
We don’t deal with foreign currency at this bank. Please go to the Korea Exchange Bank.
Where is there a Korea Exchange Bank?
Cross over the road and go towards Chongno. At the crossroads in Chongno, if you go right there is a Korea Exchange Bank.
No. It’s about five minutes on foot.

sect2.title: Is this the bus for Tongdaemun market?

entry.para: Excuse me, is there a bus for Tongdaemun market here?
I don’t have a clue, I’m not from Seoul.
Excuse me, is there a bus to Tongdaemun market from here?
No. You can’t get a bus to Tongdaemun market from here. But if you get bus number 20 it will take you to Namdaemun market.
Namdaemun market? What is there at Namdaemun market?
What is there? There’s nothing they don’t sell at Namdaemun market.
Are there more goods than at Tongdaemun market?
In my opinion Namdaemun market has more goods than Tongdaemun, and is more interesting. However, they don’t sell monkeys at Namdaemun market. They do sell them at Tongdaemun.
Is that true?! Although … I don’t need a monkey.
Take it at the stop straight across the road.
My, you must be a real stranger here (country bumpkin)! It’s 900 won.
Hurry up. The bus is coming!

sect2.title: This fruit doesn’t look too good!

entry.para: How much are the apples here?
That’s too expensive. Will you cut the price a bit?
Okay, you can take a box for 28,000 won.
Then go and try somewhere else!
Bad luck all morning (today, since the morning)!
These apples don’t look too good (fresh). Some of them have gone bad.
Really? Then I’ll cut the price a bit for you.
How much will you give me them for?
What?! That’s even more expensive than the stall next door!
All right. Then just give me 27,000 won.
Please cut me a bit more off the price.
All right, then! Just pay 25,000 a box.
Yes. The weather’s better in Korea than in England.
What are you going to do tomorrow? If you don’t have anything on, shall we go to the mountains?
I do want to go, but tomorrow I decided to go shopping at Tongdaemun market with my wife.
Next Sunday I’m thinking of going to Pulguksa with some friends from university.
Next Sunday won’t do either, then. When would be okay?
The Sunday after that would probably be fine.
All right. Then let’s go that following Sunday.
I like mountain climbing too. But there aren’t many mountains in Britain so I haven’t been able to do much. By the way, which mountain shall we go to?
Then shall we meet at the entrance to Tobongsan mountain?
I’m going into town. Shall we go together?
I don’t know … I don’t feel too good.
You don’t feel well again? You’re always pretending to be ill!
No I’m not. That’s not true. Today I really am ill.
I’ve got a nasty headache. My head hurts.
Is that all? Don’t worry – it’s perhaps because the weather is hot.
I don’t think so. I have stomach ache as well.
Then let’s go to the chemist to buy some medicine.
I can’t. I have no energy (strength). Besides, my legs hurt.
Your legs, too? It seems like your whole body hurts! Is there anywhere that doesn’t hurt?
Shut up! Don’t make fun of me. I need some medicine.
I’ve got a cure-all medicine here – it’s alcohol! It’s better than medicine, you know!
Don’t make jokes. I can’t drink alcohol. I really need to go to the hospital.
Hello. Can I speak to Chongmin, please?
I’m sorry, she was here until a little while ago, but she has just gone out.
Oh dear. Have you any idea where she might have gone?
I don’t have a clue. Just a moment. Maybe my wife will know.
Tonight Chongmin has gone out to see a movie with her boyfriend.
Really? That’s strange, she was supposed (lit: decided) to meet me this evening …
Oh dear. Well, she’s gone out on a date with a different guy and she won’t be back until late.
Oh well, it’s turned out well then – I was just ringing up to cancel. Something came up today.
Oh really? It has turned out well. Do you have a message for Chongmin?

sect2.title: What did you do last night?

entry.para: Nowadays I’m a bit busy. I’ve (just) got a girlfriend, so I’m even more busy!
I thought so. What’s her name?
She’s called Kim Chongmin. She graduated last year from Seoul National University. Now she’s working for Hyundai cars.
My friend did an introduction for me. At first I didn’t like her that much, but a month later we met by chance at a party. We started meeting regularly from then on.
And now you’re meeting her and dating nearly every day, are you?
I tried to ring you last night, but you’d gone out then too. Where did you go last night?
Last night? I don’t remember. I expect we went somewhere or other.
You don’t remember?! Had you drunk so much?!
You mean me drinking? (lit: who was drinking?) You’re the one who drinks every day (on the contrary).
We went to a noraebang, my girlfriend really likes noraebangs.
Where did you go after coming out of the noraebang?
We played a bit of table tennis.
Is that all? Tell me honestly!

sect2.title: We bought him that last year!

entry.para: Yes. We’re going to have to decide what to buy him.
I always decide. Please help this time.
All right. Why don’t we buy him a jumper?
He’s got ten already. He doesn’t need another one.
He doesn’t need a shirt either.
You know he doesn’t like reading.
Since Grandma likes reading it would be okay if she read it instead!
Don’t joke. Try making a better suggestion.
He doesn’t go out when it rains.
We bought him that last year.
How about a new electric razor?
We bought him that the year before. Besides, he doesn’t shave himself properly (frequently).
You see?! You don’t like my suggestions. You’d better decide, like I said at first!

sect2.title: I’m sorry, I really didn’t know!

entry.para: Excuse me. Please show me your driving licence.
Just look at the cars parked here. The cars have all been parked in the same direction.
Okay then, didn’t you see that red one-way signpost over there?
Ah, it’s a one-way street! I’m sorry. I really didn’t know.
You’ve committed a serious offence. It’s very dangerous and there is a large fine if you go into a one-way street the wrong way.
I really didn’t see the sign. Please let me off this once.
Be careful from now on. The fine is 50,000 won.
Thank you very much and keep up the good work.

sect2.title: What did you do with it?

entry.para: Excuse me, I was here yesterday with some friends and I left my bag behind.
Just let me go and have a look. Can you describe your bag?
Yes … it’s very big, black and made of leather.
There’s a briefcase. Is that it?
No, we don’t seem to have anything. Was there anything important inside?
Yes, actually. There were some important documents, some books and my bank cards.
Please wait a moment. I will ask the manager.
Hello, how can I help you?
I’ve lost my bag – yesterday I ate here and left it behind (put it down and left).
What time did you leave the restaurant?
Around closing time … Ah yes, I remember now. There was a bag when we were cleaning this morning.
What did you do with it?
I sent it to the police station. They are keeping it there.
Can you tell me where the police station is?
Yes, go out of the restaurant and turn left and it’s on the third (small) street on your right.
Yes, I’ve got a very bad headache; I wonder if you could give me some medicine.
Yes, certainly. When did you get it?
It came yesterday. I’ve been working very hard and have had a lot of stress – probably overwork and stress is the reason.
It could be. Do your eyes hurt at all?
Have you been able to sleep?
No, my head hurts too much, and so I can’t sleep.
I see. It’s probably linked to stress, then. I recommend these tablets.
How often should I take them?
You can take one every four hours while it’s very bad. When it gets a bit easier, then just take one tablet after meals three times a day.
When you take the medicine you will feel drowsy so take care. Don’t be surprised if you feel tired easily.

sect2.title: Would you like to try it on?

entry.para: Look at that shirt; it’s really nice.
Well, I think the design is a bit old-fashioned.
No, I like them. Agassi, how much are those shirts?
Yeah, but look at it, the quality’s not very good.
Oh, I don’t know. Shall we go and look somewhere else then?
Welcome! What are you looking for?
Yes, I’m looking for casual shirts. (Something in) a bright colour. Something stylish and good quality which I can wear with jeans.
What about these? This style is very popular at the moment.
100% cotton. Would you like to try one on?

sect2.title: Do you think it suits me?

entry.para: Do you think it suits me?
Yes. But it seems/looks a bit small.
Would you like to try a bigger one?
By the way, how much is it?
Why? That’s a very good price. Only 32,000 won.
It sounds a bit expensive to me!
At Namdaemun they had a similar one for only 8,000 won.
Ah yes, at Namdaemun. It looks the same, but the quality is very different. If you buy clothes at Namdaemun, they become unusable in just two or three months, so you have to buy new ones.
Well, I don’t know. Do you reckon this shirt will last four times as long, then?
Oh, at least. And it will be a much better fit.
Mmm. I’ll go and think about it, I think.

sect2.title: Do you have a spare room?

entry.para: Do you have any free rooms, please?
Yes, we do. Would you like beds or sleeping on the floor?
One with bed and one with floor sleeping.
Certainly. It will be 50,000 won for the room with a bed, and 40,000 for the room with floor sleeping. How many nights are you staying?
Three nights, please. We may stay a little longer than that (I don’t know).
If you book for five nights or more, we offer a 5% discount.
Oh, I’ll talk about that with my wife. Is breakfast included in the price?
Yes, breakfast is included. Between 7 and 10 a.m. please go to the basement restaurant. Or you can have breakfast brought to your room for 2,000 won extra per person.
No, we’ll go to the restaurant, thank you. What other facilities does the hotel have?
We have a swimming pool, a sauna, a games room, a noraebang, a bar, a Korean restaurant and a western one.
Is there a TV and a phone in the rooms?
Of course, and there is also a mini-bar.
Oh, that’s excellent. It would be better to book for five nights, then. My wife will probably like that.

sect2.title: The towel is dirty and the food is cold

entry.para: Excuse me, I’d like to speak to the manager, please.
Excuse me, but is there a problem?
Yes, I have something to say about the hotel service.
Is there any chance you can tell me what the problem is?
I’d like to speak to the manager direct about it.
Very well, sir. Hold on a moment please.
Hello, I’m the manager. What is the problem?
It seems that there are many problems with the service at this hotel. The staff are unfriendly and unhelpful; this morning we went in for breakfast and the food was cold. Yesterday it was the same.
Really? I’m very sorry to hear that. Did you speak to the waitress about it?
Of course I spoke to the waitress! She was impolite, and while saying that she couldn’t understand my Korean, she said that the food was fine. It wasn’t; it was cold and the taste was awful.
I’m extremely sorry, sir. We always try to do our best, but sometimes mistakes happen. I’ll make sure that I speak to the kitchen staff right away.
And that’s not all. This morning I asked for my towel to be changed and the new towel was very dirty and they still haven’t cleaned my son’s room.
This is strange. We don’t usually get any complaints like this.
Even that is not all. The television in our room has broken down and the fridge door won’t even open. I have to say that quite frankly the service and facilities are rubbish.
I’m sorry but we also don’t need guests like you who complain so much in our hotel. Please leave right away. We will refund your money.
Are there any trains to Taegu this evening, please?
Yes, there are two trains, a slow one at 5.30, and a fast one at 7.45.
The fast one takes three hours, the slow one four hours 30 minutes.
Yes, the slow one is 18,000 won, the fast 45,000 won, and we only have a few seats left for the fast one.
Can we book four seats together?
Please wait a minute. Just let me check … yes, that’s fine. There are four seats available. Non-smoking or smoking?
Would you like single tickets or return?
There’s a train at 6.30; but it’s a slow one. There is no fast train on Sunday evening.
That’ll be okay. We’ll take the fast one, please.
That will be 360,000 won altogether, please.
What platform does the train go from?
I don’t know yet. Before the time of departure look at the electronic notice board.

sect2.title: I don’t want to go there!

entry.para: What are you doing after work this evening?
After work? Don’t know. I haven’t got anything planned.
What about going out for a meal?
Sounds a good idea. Just the two of us?
We could invite some others. What about Mrs Kim and Mrs Lee?
Yeah, sure! Hey, Mrs Kim, Mrs Lee! Do you fancy going out for a meal tonight?
Okay, but where are we going to?
We could go and eat pulgogi, and of course we could drink soju and then go out to a noraebang or something.
I like drinking, but I don’t particularly like pulgogi, and I hate singing.
Well you don’t have to eat pulgogi, you can have something else. And you can just listen instead of singing.
Yeah, that’s fair enough. But I don’t have much spare cash right now.
Yes, okay then. That’s nice of you.
What about you, Mr Lee, would you like to come?
I would like to go, but I’d prefer to go out to Inchǒn and eat raw fish, though.
No, it’s too far and it’s too expensive.
Besides, I can’t eat raw fish.
Okay, okay, it was only an idea. I guess I’ll just have to come and eat pulgogi and soju!

sect2.title: Exercises on Korean alphabet
sect2.para: Exercise 3: 1 Pakistan 2 Mexico 3 New Zealand 4 The Netherlands 5 Sweden 6 Denmark 7 Indonesia 8 Poland 9 Canada 10 America
Exercise 4: 1 hotel 2 piano 3 computer 4 television 5 radio 6 taxi 7 lemon 8 ice cream 9 hamburger 10 sandwich 11 orange juice 12 tennis 13 camera 14 tomato

sect2.title: Exercises on romanization
sect2.para: Exercise 2: 1 Ǒttaeyo? 2 Saram 3 Sǒnsaengnim 4 Aniyo 5 Samushil 6 Mannada 7 Miguk 8 Hakkyo 9 Taesagwan 10 Chǒmshim

sect2.title: Unit 1
sect2.para: Exercise 1: a Chigǔm ilbon-e kayo. . b Ajǒssi, maekchu issǒyo? c Mwo sa-rǒ kage-e kayo? d Yangju-hago ojingǒ chuseyo. . e Kǔrigo anju-do chuseyo. . f Na-do kage-e kayo. . g Maekchu-hago marǔn anju-hago pap ta issǒyo. . Or, Marǔn anju-hago maekchu-hago pap ta issǒyo. .
Exercise 2: a ppang issǒyo. . b maekchu issǒyo. . c sulchip issǒyo. . d kwail issǒyo. .
Exercise 3: 1 Hakkyo-e kayo. . 2 Kamsa hamnida. . 3 Annyǒng haseyo! . 4 Ne, chal chinaessǒyo. . 5 Maekchu mashi-rǒ sulchib-e kayo. . 6 Kǔrǒm, maekchu-hago soju chuseyo. .
Exercise 4: a kayo Chigǔm hakkyo-e kayo. . b issǒyo Soju issǒyo? c sayo Mwo sayo? d mǒgǒyo Kim sǒnsaengnim ppang mǒgǒyo. . e ǒpsǒyo Ojingǒ ǒpsǒyo. . f haeyo wo ha-rǒ sulchib-e kayo? g anjayo Anjayo!

Exercise 5: a Kage-esǒ mwo sayo? Or Mwo sa-rǒ kage-e kayo? b Kim sǒnsaengnim, annyǒng haseyo! c Kǔ-daum-e mwo haeyo? d Chigǔm shinae-e kayo? e Ǒdi kayo? f Maekchu-hago kwail-hago ppang – ta issǒyo! g Pap-do chuseyo. h Ojingǒ yǒgi issǒyo. Mashikke tǔseyo! i Yangju ǒpsǒyo. Kǔrǒm maekchu hana chuseyo. . j P’ajǒn-hago soju hana chuseyo. .
Exercise 6: a Ajǒssi, ojingǒ chuseyo. . b Ajǒssi, wisk’i chuseyo. . c Ajǒssi, mul chuseyo. .
Exercise 7: a One soju, one beer and some dry snacks. b Squid, fruit, western spirits and one beer.

entry.para: Ne. Kach’i kayo. Kǔrigo sul mashi-rǒ sulchip-e kayo. .
(to the waiter) Ajǒssi, maekchu hana-hago soju hana chuseyo. .

sect2.title: Unit 2
sect2.para: Exercise 1: a ssi, do, e d ga b rǒ, e, yo e nǔn, i c ǔn

Malssǔm mani tǔrǒssǒyo. . h Ilbon kage-eyo? i Na-do hanguk sǒnsaengnim manna-rǒ kayo. . j Pak sǒnsaengnim puin manna-rǒ wassǒyo. . k Hanguk hakkwa-ga ǒdi-eyo? l Hakkyo samushir-i ǒdi-eyo?

sect2.para: Exercise 1: a Then let’s go together. b Do you have (free) time today at lunchtime? c It’s really been a long time (since we’ve seen each other). d I’m not the Japanese language teacher. e I’m sorry. I made a mistake. f Next Monday will perhaps be okay. g Since I’m not from Seoul either, I really don’t know. h So your whole body hurts, then?! Is there anywhere that doesn’t hurt? i I’d like to change English currency into Chinese. j And I’d like to eat some naengmyon as well. k Give us some dried snacks and some Korean pancake, please. l You can take them for 20,000 won a box.

Exercise 4: a Ǔmshig-ǔl mǒg-ǔl ttae iyagi (mal) ha-ji maseyo. . b Chuch’a ha-l ttae choshim haseyo. . c Shinae-e ka-l ttae na-hant’e chǒnhwa hae-juseyo. . d Yǒnghwa-ga kkǔnna-l ttae shiktang-e kapshida. . e Toch’ak haess-ǔl ttae maekchu hana mashyǒssǒyo. . f Naga-l ttae kach’i kapshida. .

Exercise 5: a Anyhow, what have you decided to do now? b Didn’t you see my girlfriend? If you see her (please) give me a call. c If you get a bit better don’t take the medicine any more. d When will you graduate? What plans have you got after that? e Are these papers important? Of course they’re important! It’s my driving licence, stupid! f When we have a date, we often go to see a movie.

Exercise 6: a K’ǔn shilsu-rǔl hasyǒssǒyo. . b Pam nǔtke toshi-e kamyǒn wihǒmhaeyo. . c Kǔ sajǒn chom poyǒ jushigessǒyo? Igǒ ǒdi-sǒ sashyǒssǒyo? d Musǔn munje-ga innayo? Ne. Nae yag-ǔl irǒbǒri-n kǒt kat’ayo. . e Yojǔm st’ǔresu-rǔl nǒmu mani pada-sǒ, pam-e cham-ǔl chal su ǒpsǒyo. . f Kabang-ǔl irǒbǒri-syǒssǒyo? Mwo-ga tǔrǒ innayo? g Nae saenggag-ǔl choaha-ji anch’anayo. . h Kǔraesǒ mwol hashyǒssǒyo?
Exercise 7: Take two tablets every three hours while it’s very bad. When it gets a bit better, then take one tablet before meal only at lunchtime.

sect2.title: Unit 11
sect2.para: Exercise 1: a . b . c d . e f . g . h i

Exercise 2: a Myǒn-ǔro mandǔn ot. . b Ǒje uri-ga mashin maekchu. . c Kim sǒnsaengnim-i il-ko innǔn chaek. . d Kǔ saram-i ip-ko innǔn shyǒch’ǔ. . e Changnyǒn-e uri-ga pon yǒnghwa. . f Nae-ga shirǒha-nǔn ǔmshik. .

Exercise 3: a Choa poyǒ-do, an choayo. . b Pissa-do, mash-i issǒyo. . c Pi-ga wa-do, naga-go ship’ǒyo. . d Kǔ saram-ǔl choaha-ji ana-do, manna-yagessǒyo. . e Palgǔn saeg-ira-do, ǒulli-ji anayo. . f Mǒri-ga ap’a-do, noraebang-e kalkka haeyo. .

entry.para: Kǔraedo kǔ yǒnghwa-nǔn chǒngmal chaemi ǒmnǔn kǒt kat’ayo. .
Kǔraedo kǔ yǒnghwa-nǔn chǒngmal chaemi ǒmnǔn kǒt kat’a. .

sect2.para: Exercise 5: a Hangugmar-ǔl chal hanǔn saram-i wayo. . b Ǒje san os-ul choaha-ji anayo. . c Kǔ saram-ǔn mǒshinǔn saram-ieyo. . d Chir-i tǒ choa-do ne bae-na pissayo. . e Tangshin-i ip-go innǔn os-ǔl ibǒ pol su issǒyo? f Mworaguyo? g Sul mashi-ji anass-ǒdo, pam-e unjǒnhal ttae choshimhaseyo. . h Pisǔt han kǒ issǒyo?

sect2.title: Unit 12
sect2.para: Exercise 1: a Haksaeng-i myǒnmyǒng-imnikka? b Mǔsǔn shisǒl-dǔr-i issǔmnikka? c Hangungmal-hago chunggungmar-ǔl kongbu hal su issǔmnikka? d Myǒnmyǒng-i hangungmar-ǔl kongbu hamnikka? e Chǒmshim shigan-ǔn myǒt-shi-imnikka? f Chǒmshim shigan-e pap mǒg-ǔrǒ chip-e ka-do toemnikka?
Exercise 2: a Pin pang issǒyo? b Ne. Ch’imdae-bang chuseyo. . c Ilgop-sal-hago tasǒt-sar-ieyo. . d Sam-il tongan-iyo. . e Aniyo. Chikchǒp shiktang-e kasǒ mǒkkessǒyo. .
Exercise 3: a Muǒs-ǔl hashyǒsssǔmnikka? b Chimdaebang hana chushipshio. . c Chǒ saram-ǔn Kim sǒnsaengnim-ishimnikka? d Na-nǔn paekhwajǒm-e kamnida. e Radio-rǔl tǔr-ǔmyǒnsǒ ch’aeg-ǔl ilksǔmnida. .

Exercise 4: a If you book for more than a week, we’ll give you a 10% discount. b To be (perfectly) honest, I hate people like that. c He said that he had (or, he has) already eaten breakfast. d A room with a floor mattress is 20,000 won per day. e It will be okay if you get up at 7 o’clock. f We can’t give you a refund (of the fare). g Two rooms with (Western) beds, please. h If you’ve got something to say (comments to make) about this hotel, please speak to the manager.
Exercise 5: a I hot’er-e sauna shisǒr-i issǔmnikka? b Ach’im shiksa-rǔl paedal hae-jumnikka? c I hot’er-e suyǒngjang-i issǔmnikka?

Exercise 6: a Myǒch’il tongan yeyak hasyǒssǔmnikka? b Chǔkshi unhaengwon-hant’e yaegi haessǔmnida. . c I hot’er-e musǔn shisǒl-dǔr-i issǔmnikka? d Nae ch’a-e munje-ga manǔn kǒt kat’-ayo. . e Nae adǔr-ǔn aji-kkaji irǒna-ji anassǒyo. . f Uri-nǔn chǔkshi ba-e kasǒ sul mashil kǒeyo. . g Kim sǒnsaengnim-ǔn pulch’injǒl han saram-ieyo. . h Sam-il tongan mungnǔn ke chok’essǒyo. .

sect2.title: Unit 13
sect2.para: Exercise 1: a There are not many seats left. b You can’t eat something different. c Would you like a return ticket? d Mountain climbing is really awful. (I really hate it …) e It looks as if I’ll have to go, then. f We were just going to have (intending to have) a game of baseball. g Is there a train going to Mokp’o this afternoon? h That’s a decent idea (surprise!).

Exercise 2: a Chǒmshim mǒk-ki chǒn-e . Chǒmshim mǒg-ǔn taǔm-e . b Ǒmǒni-hant’e chǒnhwa ha-gi chǒn-e . Ǒmǒni-hant’e chǒnhwa ha-n taǔm-e . c Nol-gi chǒn-e . No-n taǔm-e . d Shinmum-ǔl ilk-ki chǒn-e . Shinmun-ǔl ilk-ǔn taǔm-e .
Exercise 3: a 20.00 (10 p.m.) b 8.00 c 11.00 d No, there isn’t. e Yes, there is.
Exercise 4: a Chib-e toraga-l su pakk-e ǒpsǒyo. . b Ton-ǔl nae-l su pakk-e ǒpsǒyo. . c Ach’im yǒsǒt-shi-e irǒna-l su pakk-e ǒpsǒyo. .

Exercise 5: a Na-nǔn kogi malgo kwail mǒk-ko ship’-ǒyo. . b Na-nǔn suyǒng malgo nonggu ha-go ship’-ǒyo. . c Na-nǔn shinmun malgo sosǒl chaek ilk-ko ship’-ǒyo. . d Na-nǔn norae ha-ji malgo ǔmak tǔt-ko ship’-ǒyo. .

Exercise 6: a Ch’ulbal shigan chǒn-e (or, Ch’ulbal ha-gi chǒn-e), mǒg-ǔl kǒ-rǔl saseyo. (or ), . b Pumonim-hant’e yaegi halkkayo? c Na-do ka-go ship-chiman, nǒmu mǒrǒyo. . d Se chari-rǔl hamkke yeyak hal su issǒyo? e Sǒul malgo Inch’ǒn-e kapshida. . f Il kkǔnna-n daǔm-e mwol halkkayo? g Ǒnje tora-o-shigessǒyo? h Saengsǒnhoe choaha-seyo?

sect2.title: Unit 14
sect2.para: Exercise 1: a Since Mum likes watching movies, she can go to the cinema instead of Dad. b It’s probably due to stress. c In fact (actually) there were some very important papers inside. d (My) jeans have worn out (become unusable). e My wife will perhaps know. f Tomorrow evening after work I’m planning to go to the mountains. g You never like my ideas (or, opinions). h The door to our room doesn’t even open. i Could you tell me where the library is, please (lit: could you teach me …)? j Did you drink so much alcohol (as that)? k It’s a very popular style nowadays. l Show me your driver’s licence, please.

Exercise 2: a Yagu hae boshyǒssǒyo? Ne. Hae bwassǒyo. Sashir-ǔn ǒje hae bwassǒyo. . b Suyǒng hae boshyǒssǒyo? Ne. Hae bwassǒyo. Sashir-ǔn ǒje hae bwassǒyo. . c T’aku hae boshyǒssǒyo? Ne. Hae bwassǒyo. Sashir-ǔn ǒje hae bwassǒyo. . d Ch’um ch’wo boshyǒssǒyo? Ne. Hae bwassǒyo. Sashir-ǔn ǒje hae bwassǒyo. .
Exercise 3: a . b . c . d . e .

Exercise 4: a Chǒngmallo p’yojip’an-ǔl mot pwassǒyo. . b Ch’ongbaji hago kach’i ibǔl su issǒyo. . c Yaksog-ǔl ch’wiso ha-ryǒgo chǒnhwa haessǒyo. . d Pang-e chǒnhwa-hago t’erebi-ga issǒyo? e Sǒbisu-ga ǒnmang-ieyo. . f Changnyǒn-e kǔ saram-hant’e yangmar-ǔl sa juǒssǒyo. . g Chom chag-ǔn kǒt kat’-ayo. . h Kǔrǒn chul arassǒyo. . i Inch’ǒn-e kasǒ saengsǒnhoe-rǔl mǒk-ko ship’-ǒyo. . j Cha-ga ǒttǒk’e saenggyǒssǒyo? k P’yǒnji han jang ssǒ jushigessǒyo? l Mǒri-ga nǒmu ap’asǒ cham-ǔl mot chayo. .

Exercise 6: a If you do it wrong (if you don’t do it properly), it’s very dangerous. b Do you have a message for Poktong? c We deliver it to your room (lit: the guest’s room). d I was here yesterday. I left my jumper. e The girl said that it was good quality. f I’ve got a new girlfriend and it seems as if we’re out every day. g Don’t talk; just listen. h Take one tablet twice a day after meals. i Look at this! The quality’s pretty bad. j You wouldn’t know where he/she has gone, would you? k How would a new television be? l A similar thing is about twice as cheap at Namdaemun.
Exercise 7: Anio, pappǔn ir-i issǒyo. Waeyo? Woryoir-ǔn ǒttaeyo? Kǔraeyo? P’at’i-ga issǒyo? Abǒji-hant’e mwol sa-dǔrilkkǒeyo? Hwayoir-ǔn ǒttaeyo? Kǔ-ttae-nǔn shigan issǒyo? Cho-ǔn saenggag-ieyo. .

entry.para: Ani. Kǔnyang shiktang-e kasǒ kach’i chǒnyǒk hanǔn kǒ-ya. .
Hwayoir-ǔn ǒttae? Kǔ ttae-nǔn shigan issǒ?
Anida. Kǔnyang shiktang-e kasǒ kach’i chǒnyǒk hanǔn kǒ-da. .
Hwayoir-ǔn ǒttǒ-ni? Kǔ ttae-nǔn shigan iss-ni?

sect2.para: Exercise 9: a Chigǔm ǒdi kashimnikka? b Chumun haesssǔmnikka? c Ilgop shi-e irǒnamnida. . d Ppalli hae-jushipshio. . e Chǒ saram-ǔn pulch’inchǒl han saram-imnida. .

Exercise 10: Ach’im ilgop-shi-e irǒnassǒyo. . Ach’im-ǔl mǒg-ǔn daǔm-e ahop-shi-e kyohoe-e kassǒyo. . Yǒl-du-shi-e yǒja ch’ingu hago kach’i chǒmshim-ǔl mǒgǒssǒyo. . Se-shi-e kich’a-rǔl t’ago Pusan-e kassǒyo. . Ilgop-shi-e yǒnghwa-rǔl pwassǒyo.
Exercise 11: a . b . c . d . e . f . g . h . i j . k l
